steps.title: Self-reflection is thinking about yourself and trying to improve.
steps.content: Self-reflection is thinking about yourself and trying to improve. There are tons of ways to self-reflect, but at its core, self-reflection is just about asking questions about yourself and as a result, getting to know yourself better. [1] X Research source That way, you can know who you are, where you’re going, and why you’re headed in that direction. Everything about yourself is fair game for self-reflection: your thoughts, emotions, desires, strengths, weaknesses, opinions, politics… All of these are part of what makes you, you!

steps.title: Keep a journal where you jot down and ponder your own thoughts.
steps.content: Keep a journal where you jot down and ponder your own thoughts. Research shows that when you put your thoughts into writing, you get better at examining them. [2] X Research source Take 5-10 minutes each day to journal and reflect on how your day went, along with anything you feel thankful for. Journaling is a great way to curb any negative or unproductive thoughts while helping you look toward the future. You might write about a frustrating experience at work, a tough conversation you had with a friend, or an upcoming event that’s stressing you out. You could also jot down something you did well, or something that made you really happy. It’s okay if your journaling seems jumbled—what matters most is that you’re transforming your thoughts into words.

steps.title: Investigate your emotions to better understand why you feel them.
steps.content: Investigate your emotions to better understand why you feel them. Every once in a while, stop and try to name what emotion you’re currently feeling, whether it’s happiness, sadness, anger, or something completely different. If you can name your emotion, you can better understand it , and it doesn’t feel so alien or scary. [3] X Research source If you can’t name it, try to describe it! Also ask yourself why you’re feeling that way, and what feeling that emotion usually makes you do , and if that’s positive or negative. Receptive, ecstatic, blessed, reassured, intrigued, resentful, and indignant are all great examples of words for your emotional vocabulary. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Set specific personal goals and track your progress.
steps.content: Set specific personal goals and track your progress. Write down your goals and outcomes for your career, as well as your spiritual, emotional, and mental health. Once a month, check in with yourself—have you reached your goals from the previous month, or are you not quite there yet? As you reflect, create new goals for the upcoming month. [5] X Research source Your goals could be “I want to be 20% more productive at work,” or “I want to give myself an extra hour of “me time” each week.” It’s okay if you don’t reach your goals right away! Self-reflection is all about the journey and becoming more in tune with yourself.

steps.title: Practice gratitude to help you reflect on all the good things in your life.
steps.content: Practice gratitude to help you reflect on all the good things in your life. Throughout the week, focus on anything you feel thankful or grateful for. Practicing gratitude can help you feel calmer, and also boost your feelings of contentment. [6] X Research source Speak your gratitude aloud. For example, say, “I’m grateful for the support system in my life,” “I’m thankful to have a roof over my head,” or “I’m thankful to have a supportive boss and co-workers” are some ways to practice gratitude.

steps.title: Confront your mistakes and try to learn from them.
steps.content: Confront your mistakes and try to learn from them. Life coach Tracey Rogers says that “You have to recognize that there are some things about you that need to change in order to be the best version of yourself.” [7] X Expert Source Tracey Rogers, MA Certified Life Coach Expert Interview. 6 January 2020. But don’t beat yourself up when you think about the past; instead, honestly identify and reflect on the mistakes you made, so you can make better, more informed decisions in the future. For instance, if you showed up late to a friend’s important event, you might set several alarms for yourself in the future. If you hurt a friend’s feelings, you could pinpoint what you said and how you said it. That way, you’ll know what not to say in the future. If you fall short of your goals, you could pinpoint what slowed you down.

steps.title: Exercise your body and meditate to nourish your mind.
steps.content: Exercise your body and meditate to nourish your mind. Regular exercise boosts your mood and helps your brain work better. [8] X Research source Walk through your neighborhood, a local park, or any other place where you can really unplug and focus on yourself. Meditation and yoga are also great ways to boost your sense of self-awareness. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source There are plenty of meditation styles to try—guided style helps you focus on a relaxing place or experience, while mantra meditation involves chanting a calming word. There’s also mindfulness meditation, which helps you focus on living in the current moment.

steps.title: Go easy on yourself as you self-reflect.
steps.content: Go easy on yourself as you self-reflect. Self-reflection isn’t just about judging or criticizing your past decisions. Instead, self-reflection helps you learn from your past so you can reach a healthier, happier future. [10] X Research source Instead of thinking “I can’t believe I made that mistake at work,” think “I’m glad I have the opportunity to reflect on my mistakes so I can do better in the future.” Instead of thinking, “I shouldn’t have said that to my sister,” think “I’m now better prepared for future conversations.”

steps.title: Self-reflect each day, even if it’s only for a few minutes.
steps.content: Self-reflect each day, even if it’s only for a few minutes. Just 10-15 minutes is enough time to help you unplug and focus on yourself. In fact, research shows that professionals who took time for self-reflection performed better at work overall. [11] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source If you don’t have a lot of free time, try self-reflecting at least once a week.

steps.title: Recruit a trusted friend to keep tabs on your self-reflection.
steps.content: Recruit a trusted friend to keep tabs on your self-reflection. Career coach Adrian Klaphaak says to “Ask people you know well and trust…to give you feedback about what they see as your core strengths.” [12] X Expert Source Adrian Klaphaak, CPCC Career Coach Expert Interview. 18 December 2018. Reach out to a friend, loved one, or other trusted individual for help. Ask this person to hold you accountable, and remind you to self-reflect frequently. This might be a text, phone call, or any other reminder that helps you remember.

steps.title: Self reflection helps you to better understand yourself.
steps.content: Self reflection helps you to better understand yourself. Ever make the same mistake over and over again? That was probably a moment for self-reflection. When you self-reflect, you try to learn why and how you think or do something. It’s like having a conversation with yourself and checking in to see how things are going, and if anything needs to change. [13] X Research source Think of self-reflection as a sort of huddle between you and yourself. You’re both the coach and the player.

steps.title: Self-reflection helps you learn and get a new perspective.
steps.content: Self-reflection helps you learn and get a new perspective. Self-reflection is about getting outside yourself in order to look inside. It’s easy to pass judgment on other people, but not so easy to judge yourself without self-reflecting. This helps you find new ways of thinking about things, which makes you a more well-rounded person. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Self reflection helps boost your self-esteem.
steps.content: Self reflection helps boost your self-esteem. It’s not always easy to look at your own rough edges, but that’s the only way to improve them! If you practice a little self-reflection, you can start striving to be the best you. And once you start to see yourself improve—at your hobbies, at work, or even just in terms of your own thoughts and opinions—that feels good, and you feel good as a result. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Self-reflection helps you make better and more informed choices.
steps.content: Self-reflection helps you make better and more informed choices. If you’re never asking how you can do something better, be it socializing, getting new skills, or just how to better manage your time, how do you expect to improve? When you self-reflect, you discover the reasoning behind your own thoughts and actions, which helps you make better decisions in the future. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Reflective questions help you better understand yourself.
steps.content: Reflective questions help you better understand yourself. Thought-provoking questions may lead to some helpful insights and help you better understand yourself and your needs. Don’t be afraid to ask yourself some difficult questions—identifying and reflecting on your weak points can help you improve in the future. Consider some of the following, and remember to also always ask “Why?” [17] X Research source What have I been avoiding? How have I been achieving my goals? How am I holding myself back? What am I most proud of? What stresses me out the most? What opportunities did I miss out on? What did I start to do but never finish? Who do I think I am? Who do I want to be? What can I do to be that person now? What are my priorities in life? How can I help other people? What have I learned from failing? What mistakes do I want to avoid in the future? What is precious to me? Who is precious to me? What sort of world do I want to live in? Who supports me? Who do I support? What do I want? What do I need? What excites me?
